Equity
Does anyone believe Ballistic Fingerprinting to be effective or advisable?
kelvin90701

Originally posted by Equity 
 Does anyone believe Ballistic Fingerprinting to be effective or advisable? 
 
 
 Fingerprinting is useless. I can change any finger print with a screwdriver.
Tim

I think it would be a good idea. The ATF and the FBI maintain a ballistic markings database for guns and bullets recovered at crime scenes. They say that they have had a lot of success with it and have been able to match thousands of bullets and guns to each other.
Patriot

I've heard both ways. Some say dropping a file down the barrel will change the "fingerprint" enough that you won't be able to track it, but others disagree. At any rate, the ATF and FBI should NOT maintain a database for that sort of thing. That's saying that gun owners are guilty until proven innocent. Besides the fact that most crime guns are unregistered anyway.
Pie
I believe that this has been implemented in Cali...and not once used to track a criminal. Sorta like registration.
JFriday

Even the name is misleading, it cost too much and has yeilded no results where it has been implemented. It is de facto registration, a way to sneak it in. Ballistic Fingerprints change with normal use so a billion dollar program would be made useless if the gun was not recovered quickly enough or if the criminal went out and got a $2.50 beaver tail file and changed it himself. It doesnt work.
Debater

But the tests can see through damage.
 
 I don't know how but it can.
JFriday

They can see damage, not through it. If the barrell is filed down (on the inside of course) then there is no way to tell what the marks used to look like. This would make the whole thing irrelevant in court. You cant say something is the murder weapon becuase the barrell had been filed down and before that it might have matched the murder weapon.
Patriot

But after such extensive filing... wouldn't the weapon be close to useless? At the very least, accuracy would be minimal, and you'd have a very low chance of a hit unless you were very very close to your victim.
JFriday
actually no, and it would not take as much filing as one would think. Another option is to just get a new barrell
kelvin90701

Originally posted by Patriot 
 But after such extensive filing... wouldn't the weapon be close to useless? At the very least, accuracy would be minimal, and you'd have a very low chance of a hit unless you were very very close to your victim. 
 
 
 Criminals don't go to the range and practice. Have you seen videos of liquor store robberies? The perps don't even aim. Olympic match grade accuracy is unimportant at "kitchen table" distances. Most violent crime with guns occurs at knife fighting range. Criminals don't ask for your wallet or the keys of your car from 50 feet away. Thus you can file away all you want and screw up the rifling and still be effective enough to kill someone at close range.
Patriot

No, I haven't seen any videos of liquor store robberies. I guess as a criminal, I would be reluctant to degrade my weapon... especially if there was a chance of getting into a shoot-out. 
 
 In my humble opinion, however, none of this justifies the "fingerprinting" of our firearms.
Patriot

Here's something for y'all. I'm not sure how accurate these claims are, but they at least will keep this debate going. :D 
 
 For ballistic 'fingerprinting' to work as proposed, all of the following assumptions must materialize: 
 
 That the firearm barrel and firing pin have not been modified, replaced, deformed from normal use, or intentionally falsified with new ballistic markings. 
 
 That all 200 million firearms lawfully possessed by Americans are brought into labs and fired to gather individual ballistic 'fingerprinting.' 
 
 That all violent criminals, and people who might become one, also bring in their firearms for 'fingerprinting.' 
 
 That all ballistic 'fingerprinting' files are stored in a national database. 
 
 That an expended bullet or shell casing be recovered from a crime scene. 
 
 That the bullet or shell casing conclusively match the ballistic 'fingerprinting' of a firearm owned by a person stored in the database. 
 
 That the firearm has not been sold, transferred, stolen or gifted to another person. 
 
 That the person, now a criminal suspect, still possess that firearm at a current address. 
 
 Police criminalists and forensic scientists have studied such a system and called it 'impractical' [California Department of Justice, Bureau of Forensic Services].
 {Excerpt from Bush, NRA Differ on Gun 'Fingerprinting', found at NewsMax.com} 
 
 
 
 This info is found at: http://www.handguncontrolinc.org/noful3.htm
 
 (WARNING: This site is a parody.)
kelvin90701

"Canada's political rulers originally projected a $2 million budget to cover the cost of building and running a much-touted "universal" firearm registry, but now as official Auditor General's investigation has revealed the national gun registration scheme will have cost taxpayers in excess of $1 billion. And this 49,000 percent cost overrun has somehow kept secret from Parliament for years." - American Rifleman March2003
 
 All this registry wanted was names, address, and type of weapon. Think how much it would cost if they wanted to get a balistic fingerprint. It would easily be the biggest cost overrun in the history of democracy.
Fox

...also remember that Massachusetts has a registry of all handguns sold in the state. If any handgun is to be sold, including brand new ones, they have to be fingerprinted and put in a database.
 
 Crimes solved: 0.0
 
 Cost to tax payers: Millions per year
 
 Same thing in Maryland.
Patriot

the track record is that bad? I knew it was bad but not that bad. 
 
 boy am i glad I don't live in Mass. emoticon_smile
kelvin90701

Information Sarah Brady does not want you to know about ballistic fingerprints:
 
 "the examiner will measure the rifling patterns on the recovered ammunition and compare them with the General Rifling Characteristics database to see which gun models might match. The problem in some cases, however, is that "20 to 150 brands of firearms could leave the same rifling pattern,"
 
 http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?articleID=000F1BC3-9022-1DF7-9733809EC588EEDF&pageNumber=1&catID=2
tarawa12

Information Sarah Brady does not want you to know about ballistic fingerprints:
 
 "the examiner will measure the rifling patterns on the recovered ammunition and compare them with the General Rifling Characteristics database to see which gun models might match. The problem in some cases, however, is that "20 to 150 brands of firearms could leave the same rifling pattern,"
 
 http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?articleID=000F1BC3-9022-1DF7-9733809EC588EEDF&pageNumber=1&catID=2

 
 
 Not to mention different casing material will yield differnt results.
 
 The crime labs like to use "Federal" brand brass as it's softer and leaves better prints.
 
 
 However if I'm using steel cased ammo that leaves practically NO markings on the case....therefore no match.
 
 Of course if I was a criminal I would just put in my spare parts that weren't "fingerprinted" and once the job was done switch them again. The cops could never pin it to me using ballistic prints.
 
 Stupid law..period.
outdoorsman260

I agree, it won't work, for all above mentioned reasons.
 
 
 Doesn't work well with shotguns, either.
